Best robot vacuums for every budget

No matter your budget, you can have a little cleaning robot buzzing around your house.

By Leah Stodart2019-03-04 16:52:26 UTC

Robot vacuums are the hot item this season and though they could obviously make your life 100 times easier, there's a hard part to the process: picking the right one.

SEE ALSO: Pimp out your iRobot with these decorative decal skins

With so many brands, features, and app capabilities out there, deciding which vacuum you're going to drop a hefty load of cash on can be overwhelming. No worries. We hate cleaning just as much as you do and have laid out a simple, comprehensive list of all your best options, sorted by price.

ROBOT VACUUMS: $100-$300

best budget pick

Image: Housesmile
The Good
Affordable
The Bad
No room-scanning tech or app
The Bottom Line
If you want a robot vacuum and don't care about the fancy stuff, this is a great bare-bones choice.

1. Housesmile Robotic Vaccum

If you don't need the fancy stuff like an app or room-scanning tech, this high-rated device is probably your best bet.
  • Price: $129.99
See Details
At the cheapest end of the spectrum you'll find this option from Housmile, which received 5 out of 5 stars by 85% of its reviewers on Amazon. Unlike other vacuums that require a docking station, this one has a simple charging cord, and one charging session can give it enough juice for 30 minutes of vacuuming. What you sacrifice at a cheaper price point are things like room scanning technology and a mobile app, but for someone who isn't that much of a techie but wants to get in on the robot vacuum hype, this is a good option. (And it makes a great gift for grandma.) Get it for $129.99 here.


best budget choice for people with allergies

Image: PureClean
The Good
HEPA filter • 55 minute run time • 3 cleaning programs and detachable brushes
The Bad
Not rated as high as the Housesmile
The Bottom Line
If you'd like a cheap option with some extra features like a HEPA filter, this could be the robot vacuum for you.

2. PureClean PUCRC25

If you're looking for a budget model with multiple settings and a HEPA filter, here you go.
  • Price: $111.99
See Details
Another moderately priced option is this entry-level model by PureClean, which received a 5-star rating from 60% of reviewers on Amazon. This low-profile vacuum (read: it can easily fit under furniture) has a run time of 55 minutes and includes three cleaning programs. It includes detachable brushes for hardwood and tile and also has a HEPA filter. Get it for $111.99 here.


best for small spaces

Image: ECOVACS
The Good
App-enabled • Affordable • Anti-collision tech
The Bad
No room-scanning tech
The Bottom Line
If you'd like to trade up from the bare-bones models to one with an app, this is a good choice.

3. ECOVACS Deebot N79

If you're not looking for anything fancy, but just a reliable bot to get the job done, the ECOVACS Deebot N79 could be right for you
  • Price: $299
See Details
If you're not looking for anything fancy, but just a reliable bot to get the job done, the ECOVACS Deebot N79 could be right for you. This app-enabled bot has three cleaning modes, along with the anti-collision and drop sensor protection that every robot vac should have. Ideal for smaller spaces or apartments, the highly-rated Deebot N79 is available for $299 here.


best for quiet cleaning

Image: Eufy
The Good
Quiet • Works on hard floors and carpet • Features infrared obstacle sensors
The Bad
No app • No room-scanning tech
The Bottom Line
If you're just looking for a sensible quiet option that works on carpet and hard floors, this could be it.

4. Eufy RoboVac 11

If you want a quiet robo-vac that works on hard floors and carpet, this budget option could be your best bet.
  • Price: $179.99
See Details
If you're tired of having to plan your cleaning time around other people's sleep, TV, or studying, the Eufy RoboVac 11 might be a good option. Unlike an obnoxiously loud upright vacuum, the Eufy RoboVac 11 is reportedly pretty quiet — even in the high suction mode. Working on both hardwood floors and carpet, the Eufy RoboVac has infrared obstacle sensors as well as two power options that can be operated by the remote control and is decently priced at $179.99.


ROBOT VACUUMS: $300-$500


best for homes with pets

Image: Neato
The Good
Lots of features to remove pet hair • D-shape gets into corners • Has room-scanning tech
The Bad
Not app-enabled
The Bottom Line
If you don't need an app, but do need to get rid of pet hair, this is one of the best options.

5. Neato BotVac

This robot vacuum was made for homes with pets, and has extra features to combat the scourge of shedding.
  • Price: $499
See Details
Ideal for homes with pets, the letter "D" shaped Neato BotVac D80 can easily get into corners, where hair and other allergens love to gather (and where circular robot vacuums have a harder time reaching). Other pet-friendly features include an opening port shaped specifically to combat hair clogging and a combo brush uniquely designed to pick up pet hair. Though it's not Bluetooth or app enabled, the Neato BotVac uses laser smart mapping to scan rooms and methodically plan how to clean instead of just bumping around. Get it for $499 here.


ROBOT VACUUMS: $500-$700


best "budget" Roomba

Image: Roomba
The Good
Works on carpet and hard floors • App-enabled, with scheduling • iAdapt navigation
The Bad
Not the least pricey
The Bottom Line
If you have your heart set on a Roomba, this entry-level model could be the one, but it's not exactly cheap.

6. Roomba 650

If you want a Roomba but you're on a budget, this highly-rated pick could be for you.
  • Price: $510.99
See Details
If you're set on getting a Roomba but don't want to fork over almost a grand, the Roomba 650 is a happy middle ground. Working on both hardwood and carpeted floors, your obsessive Swiffering may finally decrease. The app allows you to schedule sessions up to seven times per week, and the iAdapt Navigation claims that you won't come home to find it stuck on a chair. Get the highly-rated Roomba 650 for $510.99 here.


best mid-range option

Image: Roomba
The Good
AeroForce system loosens dirt on carpets • Cleans for 75 minutes on one charge • App-enabled and works with Alexa and Google Assistant • Highly rated
The Bad
Still pricey
The Bottom Line
If you're ready for a mid-range Roomba, this one has a lot of bells and whistles.

7. Roomba 960

If you're looking for a Roomba with more options than the basic model, this one has a ton of features.
  • Price: $699
See Details
The Roomba 960 is the drool-worthy combination between price and quality. Its AeroForce system loosens dirt on even the most stubborn carpets and uses patented tangle-free brushes to combat pet hair, and cleans for 75 minutes before returning to charge itself. Compatible with the iRobot app as well as Amazon Alexa and the Google Assistant, the 960 wants to ensure that you can schedule cleaning simply and come home to clean floors. Listed for $699, it's actually pretty generously priced considering how highly it's rated. Get it here.


best Star Wars-themed robot vacuum

Image: Samsung
The Good
Fun! • Talks and plays music from Star Wars • Uses CycloneForce tech
The Bad
If you're not a Star Wars fan, this is a pricey option
The Bottom Line
This one is super-fun and that alone might make it worth the price.

8. Samsung POWERbot Star Wars

If you're a die-hard Star Wars fan, you basically legally have to own this robot vacuum.
  • Price: $699.99
See Details
Looking to have some fun with your robot vacuum? These Star Wars edition POWERbots by Samsung are styled after Darth Vader and a Stormtrooper, play music from the movies, and even talk. They both use CycloneForce technology and do a pretty good job at getting the edges of walls, stairs, and other 90-degree angles. The Stormtrooper is $699.99.


ROBOT VACUUMS: $700+


best for large spaces

Image: Roomba
The Good
Runs for up to 120 minutes on a charge • Double the suction of the 960 model • Carpet-boost technology not found in the 960
The Bad
Still pricey
The Bottom Line
If you need to cover a large space, especially if carpets are involved, this is a great model.

9. Roomba 980

This Roomba has all the bells and whistles, is great for large spaces, and recently lowered its price.
  • Price: $869.95
See Details
If your home is on the larger end of the spectrum, the Roomba 980 may be the right robot vacuum for you. Because it runs for up to 120 minutes before automatically returning to charge, the 980 is ideal for bigger spaces that require more cleaning. The 980 also uses the dirt-loosening AeroForce technology, but has double the suction of the 960 and uses carpet boost technology that the 960 does not. Plus, it's recently gone down in price significantly. Snag it for $869.95 here.


best for millionaires

Image: Dyson
The Good
Twice the suction of any other robot vacuum • App that lets you schedule cleanings and analyze data • Very high-level room-scanning tech • The best of the best
The Bad
Extremely expensive
The Bottom Line
If you want the best of the best, this is probably it, but you'll pay for it.

10. Dyson 360 Eye

The Dyson 360 Eye boasts every bell and whistle imaginable, but you could buy an army of budget vacuums for the same price.
  • Price: $998.99
See Details
This one is the motherlode. Claiming to have twice the suction of any other robot vacuum, the Dyson 360 Eye uses Radial Root cyclone technology, which is a minimized version of the tech used in Dyson's upright vacuums. The app allows you to control, schedule, and analyze cleaning data like high debris areas. Dyson also claims that the Eye 360 creates a map as it goes, knowing where it's already cleaned and where it needs to clean. Get it for $998.99 here.

 

And, if nothing else, you should just get one to do this.
